thread.section_title: Oklahoma Sooners News - Sports News for Dallas, Texas
thread.title: Oklahoma fans seek out cheaper seats in Texas' territory at Red River Showdown
thread.title_full: Oklahoma fans seek out cheaper seats in Texas' territory at Red River Showdown | Dallas Morning News

author: MEREDITH SHAMBURGER
title: Oklahoma fans seek out cheaper seats in Texas' territory at Red River Showdown
text:
The Cotton Bowl’s 50-yard line is usually a strict demarcation between burnt orange and crimson at the Texas-OU game.
But that line was breached at Saturday’s Red River Showdown as Oklahoma fans took advantage of lower ticket sales on their opponents’ side.
Their incursions only put them in a tough spot to endure an upset defeat.
Ruben and Jose Jacquez were among the Oklahoma fans hunkered down in enemy territory during the 24-17 loss.
“Sitting in between our fans, you never really realize how loud it gets on this side,” he said of Texas’ section.
Saturday’s game brought 91,546 people to the Cotton Bowl, officials said. But Rachael Bigham and Nancé Headley were disappointed their fellow Longhorns hadn’t done more to fill their share of the stands.
“I think that people ought to be more than fair-weather fans and support Texas all the time,” said Bigham, 42.
And the diehards were rewarded for braving the game Saturday despite a 1-4 record.
“I’m so proud of this team,” said Headley, 43. “If we couldn’t have won any other game, I’m glad we won this game.”
The Longhorns came into the game ranked near the bottom of the Big 12 conference, while the Sooners were the No. 10 team in the nation.
“It’s an absolute shock,” Bigham said of Saturday’s victory. “It was an exciting game. The entire thing was awesome. I feel like we’re going in the right direction.”
And in the end, they didn’t mind sharing close quarters with their adversaries.
“The rivalry was there, but it was a friendly rivalry,” Bigham said.
“It always is,” Headley said.
